posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked:
Another year, another feedback survey. This year, we rolled out a ton of new features in response to the awesome feedback you guys gave last year. A non-exhaustive list of those features and changes below includes:

- Came out with seven (Kraken X44, WCP ThroughBore, CANdi, CANrange, Talon FXS, Minion, PDP 2.0) new products addressing a wide range of use cases.
- Various performance and portability improvements to the Swerve Generator and Swerve API.
- Introduced Java units to the API to minimize unit-related conversion errors in user code.
- Introduced Hoot Replayâ€”a super-easy way to get signals replayed from a hoot log.
- Focused on our Tuner and diagnostics support, introducing a high-performance flexible plotter.
- Lots of miscellaneous improvements for our current limitations, API shape, firmware behavior, and more.

We love feedback of our devices and use that to drive future product and software development. Weâ€™re very interested in hearing how folks used our products, our API, and more and what we can improve upon for 2026. Weâ€™d appreciate it if teams could fill out the below survey and let us know your thoughts!

[Survey link]

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: Signal log caused me some issues on rio 1. Specifically, when it writes too much data to rio 1's built-in flash (without an SD card inserted), it prevents pushing any code to rio 1 unless SSH into rio and manually remove all the new logs. Additionally, the swerve project created by the phoenix tuner has logging enabled by default.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Add Candle support to Phoenix 6. Add an option to generate Swerve as an Advantage Kit style subsystem.

posts.name: Bryce Roethel
posts.cooked: Add Candle support to Phoenix 6. Currently, this release contains CANdle feature-parity with Phoenix 6 and introductory support for LED control in Phoenix Tuner X (Tuner v2025.4.1.0). We have several CANdle and CANdle-related Tuner featuresâ€¦

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Overall since Phoenix 6 came out all the CTRE hardware and software has worked very well. One feature idea I brought up in my survey is having a way to modify current limits without a config change either per-request or per-slot. I think a lot of teams are finding a need to run with more or less aggressive current limits in different phases of a match.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
While Iâ€™m still around, I have the ability to configure a control request to cancel upon disable. This serves as a safety feature to prevent issues during testing when a bot is disabled, examined, and then re-enabled, potentially causing an elevator or arm to snap back to its position.

We currently enable a disable command for our subsystems to address these risks, but it would be both safer and more convenient if this functionality were configured differently.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Agreed. We set all our motors to voltage mode and command 0 volts. That way they donâ€™t move when the robot goes back into auto until they are commanded to go back into motion control.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Change the default name of a carnivore log to be the user-set bus name instead of the serial number of the carnivore device. Since we only had one log initially, it was straightforward to identify which one belonged to the carnivore, but introducing a second carnivore might complicate things for someone new trying to determine which log corresponds to which carnivore.

posts.name: Ryan Shavell
posts.cooked: 2025 Phoenix was fantastic! Additionally, slipping in support for the CANdle was a nice post-champs treat. To clarify further, it would be helpful to include more details on how TorqueCurrentFOC control and tuning work, such as explaining how it operates differently from traditional voltage/duty cycle-based methods and providing examples of scenarios where it offers advantages over voltage control.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: It would be nice to see the names of the devices in the hoot log rather than just the CAN Controller Area Network IDs.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
I was going to provide feedback on the Swerve API but realized my understanding was incomplete, so I decided to address it here. 

Noticing the [code]SwerveModuleConstants.SteerFeedbackType[/code] now includes the [code]TalonFXS_PulseWidth[/code] option, specifically for FXS. Within FXS configurations, the [code]ExternalFeedbackSensorSourceValue[/code] selections resemble those in the FX [code]FeedbackSensorSourceValue[/code] enum, replacing [code]RotorSensor[/code] with [code]Commutation[/code] and introducing [code]PulseWidth[/code] and [code]Quadrature[/code].

Currently, there aren't any fusing methods that sync the commutation sensor with a Gadgeteer-port sensor like a Mag Encoder. I can't imagine the velocity measurement fidelity would be high when using a direct 1:1 pulse width sensor for swerve azimuth control.

While Hall sensors on FXS offer lower fidelity compared to FX's magnetic rotor encoders, using them alongside external pulse width sensors, especially at 250Hz, may not yield satisfactory results. There appears to be a gap where a "FusedPulseWidth" mode could offer a balanced solution.

Another potential improvement could involve leveraging [code]TalonSRX_SelectedSensor[/code] remote sensors, such as borrowing an FXS/SRX sensor port for a Kraken-based setup, similar to how PowerPole adapters allow connecting CAN coders.

Regarding the Kraken series, the absence of basic external sensor interfaces, including limit switches, seems more practical than a packaging choice. However, the reintroduction of the Gadgeteer port in FXS simplifies decisions related to sensor usage near the module.
